awd_titl_txt: INFEWS: U.S.-China: An Integrated Technology-Environment-Economic Modeling Platform for FEW Systems in Arid Regions
awd_abstract_narration:
The Food-Energy-Water (FEW) Nexus, from a global perspective, contains closely interconnected resource systems of food, energy, and water. As the world's population expands to an expected 9 billion by 2050, there will be an urgent demand to balance different resources across these three systems to achieve different user goals without putting undue strain on the ecosystems that provide these resources. This research project will utilize both wet waste conversion and renewable energy sources, such as wind and solar, to produce electricity for harvesting and filtering saline water for crop irrigation and algae production in soils not normally used for such purposes. The goal of the project is to create a new modeling platform that ingrates technology, environment, and economics using research inputs from two different teams in this collaboration - one from the University of Illinois at Urban-Champaign (UIUC) and one from the China Agricultural University (CAU). This new platform could potentially be used to identify options for harnessing underutilized resources and renewable energy to produce food, particularly in arid region FEW systems (AR-FEWS). The PIs plan to test the hypothesis that harvesting non-conventional sources of water for high-value crop irrigation will be cost effective and environmentally feasible in arid regions with access to renewable energy sources. If successful, this research could strengthen FEW systems in the US and other countries in under-used arid regions by identifying economically and environmentally viable technologies to produce food and energy while conserving water resources.

Using research inputs from the U.S. and China teams, this project will develop a seamless system modeling tool that integrates technological, environmental, and economic components to conduct holistic quantitative analysis of AR-FEWS. A particular focus will be put on arid regions with marginal land and water and plentiful renewable energy sources where the synergies in resources production and use can be enhanced.  The PIs will define key parameters of the integrated system to develop process-based models, including optimization for hydrothermal liquefaction (HTL) conversion of wet biowaste and algae, wastewater treatment methods needed for algal biomass and hydroponic food production, and characteristics of food produced hydroponically with wastewater. The process models will be integrated with environmental and economic analyses at the regional scale to identify technological solutions and policy options for harnessing the potential of marginal resources and renewable energy to produce food in arid regions. The integrated modeling tool will be tested in arid areas in Northwestern China. This project will be aligned with an ongoing NSF-funded INFEWS project (INFEWS #1739788, Advancing FEW System Resilience in the Corn Belt by Integrated Technology-Environment-Economics Modeling of Nutrient Cycling) to develop a generic modeling tool that will be used to identify robust optimal solutions for sustainable and resilient FEW systems and assess the feasibility of technology adoption at regional scales.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

NSF Award 1804453 - Outcome Report

This project developed a robust, integrated system to convert biowaste into renewable fuels, recover valuable nutrients from waste streams, and improve food, energy, and water (FEW) systems in arid regions. Through innovative thermochemical processing, environmental assessment, and economic modeling, the project demonstrated a comprehensive pathway for producing sustainable bioenergy and fostering circular resource flows that enhance both environmental and economic resilience. Our approach focused on regions with limited natural resources, using waste as a resource to meet critical energy needs and improve resource sustainability.

Key Outcomes and Intellectual Merit

Along with other relevant projects of the team, this project has made significant advancements in biowaste-to-bioproducts technology by converting biowaste into biofuels through hydrothermal liquefaction (HTL). Using a pilot-scale reactor, we have successfully scaled up this conversion process, reaching a capacity to produce up to 200 L of biocrude oil per day. Through catalytic hydrotreating, HTL biocrude was further upgraded to remove impurities and enhance fuel performance, meeting ASTM standards for sustainable aviation fuels. This work contributes to the intellectual merit by pushing the boundaries of biowaste-to-biofuel technology and providing a potential drop-in fuel option that could replace or complement conventional fossil fuels in transportation, particularly in the aviation sector.

In addition to fuel production, another component of this project was the recovery of carbon and nutrients from the post HTL wastewater (PHW). Essential nutrients, including nitrogen and phosphorus, were recovered from the PHW to produce renewable fertilizers for agricultural applications. The PHW treatment also generated high-purity hydrogen gas, which could further support the upgrading of HTL biocrude in the system.

This integrated biowaste-to-bioproduct process reduces reliance on fossil-based products, lowers greenhouse gas emissions, and mitigates the environmental impacts associated with landfill disposal of biowaste. By creating a sustainable loop where waste products are continuously reused, the project promotes resource circularity and offers a scalable model for enhancing sustainability in FEW systems.

Broader Impacts and Resource Circularity

One of the standout achievements of the project is the development and application of a Circularity Index (CI), a metric designed to measure the extent of circular resource flows within bioeconomy systems. The CI, which ranges from 0 (completely linear) to 1 (completely circular), offers a quantitative framework to assess the sustainability of FEW systems. By applying the CI to our integrated system, we observed a significant improvement in circularity, from 0.179 to 0.843 after incorporating biowaste conversion and nutrient recovery. This increase demonstrates the positive impact of our approach on resource sustainability and serves as a model for implementing circular bioeconomy principles in other sectors.

Furthermore, this project had significant educational and professional impacts. Four graduate students completed their degrees with support from this project, gaining hands-on experience in cutting-edge research on bioenergy and sustainability. The project also engaged undergraduate students, providing them with valuable training in research activities and professional skills development. Through collaboration with institutions in both U.S. and China, we disseminated research findings and fostered dialogue among stakeholders form government, academia, and industry. These collaborations facilitated discussions on challenges and solutions for enhancing resilience and sustainability in FEW systems.

Conclusion

Overall, via international collaboration, this project has demonstrated a practical, scalable pathway for converting biowaste into renewable energy while fostering resource circularity and sustainability. By addressing both the intellectual and broader impacts of bioenergy production and nutrient recovery, our work has laid a foundation for resilient FEW systems in resource-limited regions. The integration of waste conversion, nutrient recycling, and environmental assessment provides a comprehensive model that could inform future efforts to enhance sustainability in agriculture, energy, and water systems across diverse environments.
